Super Cool!. My sister-in-law surprised the three of us (22 year old daughter, husband and me) with a two-hour pass to go skiing at "Ski Dubai." What! How Bizarre! We were there on a Saturday afternoon, and the whole process was so easy. Firstly, you go to a counter where they give you a ski jacket, pants and socks. Then you go to a counter where they give you ski boots. Then you put on your ski suit and one boot and give the other to the guy who fits your boot to the skis. Now you have everything, except your ski poles (complimentary helmets are also available). The pass card goes in a pocket on your jacket, so when you approach the electronic turnstyle it allows you to enter. So you go up the escalator and collect your ski poles at the top, and then you enter the most surreal atmosphere you could expect in Dubai, or pretty much anywhere! It really is like a mini ski resort! There is a 4-main chair lift and a button drag lift. Being lazy, we took the chair lift, but our daughter tried the button lift, and we found it was faster to the top than the chair. At the top, there are two runs. One is a little steeper and even has a couple of tiny moguls! The air is very cold, and the snow is not bad at all. We have a cabin in a ski resort, so I think we are fair judges when it comes to this. There are a few "planks" on one side of the run for boarders to practice their tricks, and there's also a toboggan run, but it seemed to be closed. We skied for an hour and had one of the best experiences we've had in Dubai. One tip: bring gloves, because they are not included in your ski gear, and your hands get very, very cold! You can also buy them in a shop there. If you are not a skier, or if you have small children with you, there is also a snow park to slide around. I highly recommend "Ski Dubai" as a fun diversion from the beach and shopping.

Ski slope inside a mall in the middle of the desert....welcome to Dubai. Hmm...starting to think maybe I went on a bad day as most of the reviews seem positive! Anyway....I went for a lesson along with a friend who is an experienced snow boarder (he just bought a ski pass). I was booked in around 4pm, you are advised to show up an hour early for the lesson to get your equipment together. This might sound excessive but on the day we were there, the queues were insane! It took the full hour to get my gear, which then turned out to be the wrong size but too late to change it as the lesson was starting. The whole place was a mess, equipment dumped everywhere, staff were unfriendly (so would I be if I was working there on that day, to be fair), no place to sit as it was so crowded, kids running around everywhere etc....I actually ditched the lesson as I was totally stressed and over it by that point. I just went out to the slope to watch people snowboarding/skiing instead.I think the moral of this story is to go early in the day as possible unless you have a fondness for queues and chaos. As for the slope itself, my friend described it as boring after 2 runs. Although it is nice being somewhere cold in such a hot climate, I'm also not too sure how sensible this place is in terms of energy usage.I guess if snow inside a mall sounds appealing as a novelty, or if you want to practice before a holiday, it might be worth a visit but personally I would give it a miss and wait for the real thing.

Lots of fun with 20% discount offer. We have been to Mall of the Emirates a couple of times, and always wanted to visit ski dubai. I came across a 20% discount voucher for Ski Dubai on VoucherCodesUAE dot com. We printed out 5 vouchers for 5 of us and enjoyed the park and slopes at a great value deal.

Nothing special for skiiers. First - absolutelly crazy have skiing hill in middle of desert,but money are powerfull :-) We were there with friends and our 3.5 old yrs son, he was excited from snow after beach and sea afternoon:-) Eqiupment, dresse etc is really used, I am very good skier and this ecperience is really only fun :-) It was my first slope where is FIRE EXIT! :-) We were there evening (from 8-11 pm.) and we were last clients there, staff very attention to our son,nice!

Great , novel , and a must visit.. If you ski OR snowboard then you must visit SKI Dubai. It is a bit bizarre skiing in Dubai but it is good. The hill is long enough and they have a "four man" chair lift to get you back to the top.

Welcome relief from the heat!. Fast and efficient staff and clothing hire process, well looked after equipment but need to take or buy gloves and possibly a hat! Cable car and drag lift (which is quicker to top of the run) and a cafe half way up the run accessible by the chair lift from where non skiers can watch and have a coffee. Go in the morning as the slopes get really crowded in the evenings
just ok. it is just average place for intertainment, nothing special.
We had a great time. The idea of skying on the middle of the dessert it's just amazing we snowboard the trak is small but you still have a great time

Ski Slope closed for maintenance during Ramadan. The snow park was open, but the ski slope was closed for maintenance during Ramadan. This was not posted on the website so we were disappointed to discover this when we arrived.

Ski Dubai- excellent choice for kids. We recently visited Dubai with our two kids aged 9 and 12. Since they were oblivious to the allure of shopping, we decided to enroll them in skiing lessons. It turned out to be the best decision ever. The kids absolutely loved it. There are different levels of lessons to choose from Discovery, Beginner, Intermediate 1,2 etc. The levels are recommended based on your child's skill level. Each level has a set of exercises to learn. Once is child is able to all the exercises in a level, they can move onto the next, (either the same day or the next, we chose the next day). Their prowess is recorded in "passports" which are given to them. The instructors are from different parts of the world, fabulous skiers and very child friendly. The groups are kept small and instructions are very clear. Do book the lessons in advance. It saves a lot of time when you get there if your child's details are already keyed in. Instructors vary from lesson to lesson.So if your child's first instructor has specified that your child requires attention in a certain area, do request them to write that down while they are signing off their passports. And do show this to the next instructor prior to their second lesson. And do carry your passports to all lessons. It is a good idea to be there ahead of time to allow for the time it takes to get their gear ready. My children cleared several levels and since Ski Dubai is in one of the best malls, one can get some shopping done in the meantime without having to drag unwilling children around. For those interested snow boarding lessons are also offered, both for adults as well as children. It's money well spent.

Great experience in the Middle East!. Being from a hot climate country makes easy that I love snow every time I see it. But the most amazing thing is seeing snow in the Middle East. The park is just fantastic and the snow is so real. I love every time we go to Dubai and we go to the Sky Dubai because you feel that you are not in the Middle East.One important thing you should consider: the entry fee includes the clothes and boots, and you can not take your purse with you inside, so you have to leave everything in a locker. Remember to take cash inside with you because at the top there is a cafe where you probably will like to have a hot chocolate or coffee,and they don't accept credit cards.

Excellent Experience. It's such a great fun to be able to go skiing while in the desert. I've been snowboarding for a couple of years and so glad that I visited excellent experience! Could be a bit cheaper I would happily go again, no queues and an excellent service provided when on the slopes!

Love it. This is a terrific experience, how often can you ski in the desert. The Inside of the complex is lovely, you need to insure that you go off peak hrs as it get very crowded, but during the late evening it is great to ski, the slopes are fun and be dressed warm as it gets very cold. You can also visit during the opening hrs, be aware that there are some crazy young folks on ski boards that make life tough , however it is a wonderful experience. Every-time I go into the complex I smile and think I could be in the Alps in Europe. All the workers are very helpful, make sure you bring your own warm gloves and a ski head cover.

What an Experience!. Of course Dubai is extremely hot this time of year so what better way to cool off is to go skiing inside the mall. Too fun! I stayed until the sun went down and had a wonderful time doing it. You have to experience this for yourself.

Fun for young kids. My four years old niece loved the snow park, bobsledding, tubing or just walking around was of great fun to her. For older kids, to ski or to join the ski lesson will be more appropriate. It'd be rather cold with just the gear provided. Gloves and hats are necessary while wearing clothes in addition to your tank top and shorts will make your stay there more comfortable.About tobogganing, a couple of adults had their knees and elbows bumped into the ice shafts during the run, quite dangerous according to them as no one told them what posture was appropriate.The giant ball was fun but it was charged at 30 dirhsms for each ride or needed an upgrade from the basic ticket (80 dirhams) to gain unlimited access to the chairlift, giant ball and tobogganing down the slope.Not at all amazing but it did make the trip to Dubai fun... sand, water & snow!!!!

Grwat couple of hours if you go early. We have been to Ski Dubai a few times now and always have a great couple of hours. Key is to get there early, ideally just as it opens and to do it on a week day (Sunday to Thursday). It gets more crowded a bit later. We have never had to wait for the lift or had any trouble on the slope with other users.They provide all the gear including clothes for the price. No discount if you take your own gear. The gear they give is OK and in nfact fine for the couple of hours. Snow is usually in good condition and lift is fast.There is a small resturant half way that does great hot chocolate. Don't forget to take your own hat and gloves other wise you'll freeze your hands. but some cheap ones are for sale at the place.Suggest to get hold of a copy of the Dubai Entertainer for a buy one get one free coupon.

Great escape from the heat!. .I recently checked out SKI DUBAI for the first time. I thought it was an enjoyable way to spend a few hours and it was a great escape from the heat of the Dubai afternoon. I went on a Thursday and the number of skiers on the slope was comfortable. (It can get quite crowded on Fridays and Saturdays.)Entrance cost was about $50USD for a two hour ski pass. (Note: The Entertainer Book has buy one, get one free coupons.) The cost includes all necessary equipment and ski pants and jacket. It does not include gloves though. (Gloves are available for purchase near the entry way.) Lockers are available for a nominal fee.The skiing was pretty basic, however since I hadn't skied for about five years it took a few runs for me to get used to it again. I would have liked to have "practiced" on the "bunny slope" first, however only those taking lessons have access to it. It's a great time for the intermediate skier. If you're a really good skier, you may get bored going down the same run over and over... however it feels great to be in the cool air no matter what your experience level is.Additional Notes: The snow park portion is a separate ticket. A day pass for the ski slope is also available

Kinda boring.. After seeing so many travel shows high lighting Ski Dubai, it would have been disappointing coming all the way to Dubai and not at least check it out. The idea of skiing in the middle of the desert seemed so bizarre that I had to do it. Truth be told I was a bit bored, and was not all that impressed. It's the skiing equivalent of an indoor ice skating rink. The only problem is you can go from the top to the bottom in a couple of minutes. After going up and down twice you're pretty much ready to leave. If you've never skied or boarded before, then it would probably be more fun. The problem is skiing is an outdoor sport where half the fun comes from exploring different terrains. I was more impressed by the aquarium at the Dubai Mall. Scuba diving there gives you a chance to get up close with a high concentration of fish, which would rarely happen out in the ocean.Come to Ski Dubai to at least see it. If you decided to give it a go, don't plan on staying there too long.

Snow Sking In The Dessert ?. 20 years have passed since i last went sking so I was more than a little nervous about hitting the slopes again but where else can you do this in the dessert .All the photos I had seen on this attraction just didn,t do it justice , it is huge with all kinds of attractions for the little ones thru to the not so little .On our arrival we had to decide which of the ticket types that we wanted so I went for the Mega Pass that does everything and my wife who is not a skier just went for the slides and rides .After a bit of confusion be one of the staff over what we were actually doing and which equipment to issue us we were on our way , it is important to note here that they issue all the gear you will need with the exception of gloves and a warm hat , you can buy them from the ski shop next door but it is rather expensive so bring your own like we did .I did a practice runs ( ok ,i did more than a few ) on the bunny slope ( out the door and immediatly on your left ) for a while to get my legs , balance , coordination and feet back and when i felt confident enough i went up the big slope .We both had a ball and the staff were all very helpful .The only thing that i could remark on was that the slope was rather icy and hard with very little powder on it so that made the whole thing really fast , I wouldn,t recomend doing this if you have never skied before or have limited experiance as you will end up eating snow and this of course had me doing a few face plants along the way .Value wise it,s good but i wouldn,t buy the Mega Pass unless you intended to do and had the energy to do all the activities .Just buy the Slope Pass if all you wanted to do was ski , it,s good for 2 hours and you will have bags of fun .Afterwards a hot coco from one of the cafes that overlook the slope is most welcome and you can use a discount voucher for it that came with your tickets .And don,t forget to hand in your locker key cards for a refund on the deposit for them we did fortunatly we were back there 2 days later for some shopping and still got the refund back so alls good .Peter and Sue

ok, but not great if you're a good skiier. This was very well set out, and bizarre putting ski clothes over your shorts and t shirts, then walking in from humid conditions to what is like walking into a freezer. the chair lift was slow and had lines of people waiting, if you're a good skiier then you will find this probably a bit too tame ski lessons are offered to all either individually or as a group. it passed a couple of hours and we didn't do the sledging. Younger children will get most fun from this.

Amazing Indoor Snow Park!. SkiDubai is located inside the Mall of Emirates, you can take the direct Metro Train to the mall its connected with it!! It is an amazing indoor snow park, although expensive but it is worth every penny! You have several options to choose from either you can sky and do other sports or just go for a visit to the park! Once you are inside you can have hot chocolate with is an amazing experience.
a nice 2 hours fun. i am from a skiing resort in Austria ,i live now in Dubai since 6 years ,i enjoyed this 2 hours very much and i will do it again very nice staff and giood organiced

ski is expensive, snow park is a total waste of money. ski is something to see but expensive.
the snow park is a total waste of money. its very limited and once you enter they will ask you upgrade for everything little slide/ride. please dont waste your money like i did going to the snow park. just go skiiing if you don't mind the price.
A great facility. Highly recommended!. Excellent indoor ski slope in Dubai. Huge king runs, chair lift and pomma tow. Price is on the high side but a must-do experience when visiting Dubai.

Ski in the Desert - A Must See & Do. Ski Dubai was a fantastic experience and was a well managed venue. Myself and father (who have never been on the slopes before) decided to have a very beginner lesson (called a 'Discovery' session). We booked and used a 20% off discount voucher that we got from our hotels check-in desk. On the day of our Ski we bought gloves from the small ski store right next to the ticket desks. The gloves were very good value and the only thing we needed to buy as the Skis, Coat, Trousers and disposable socks where all included in the hire price of the lesson. The only part of the experience that didn't seem overly organised was the equipment hire and waiting for the tutor, at there were no instructions or help available and very few staff around.We got our locker and got ready for the slopes.After a short wait our tutor got our small group of about 7 together and took us through to the slope.The 60 min session went quickly but was in no way rushed. The tuition was fantastic and of a very high standard. The group moved along very quickly and were perfectly pushed and encouraged by the tutor. By the end of the first lesson we were all moving down the mid slope unaided with only a few falls.A great experience and well worth the money. We thought the value was excellent (much better than in the UK!).We look forward to going back and doing the next course (beginner) to learn even more from the great experienced team at Ski Dubai

Nothing else like it - ITS A MUST DO. It is just one of those must do things. And yes, you must do it. I had a ball. For me the crowds were down so it was just ski on ski off a great two hours. Having only one run means you only need two hours. For those a bit unsure, you can get lessons and mid station is a green run. If you wanta go to the top the right side (as look up) is the easy blue and the left is the harder blue.They supply everything except gloves and beanie. I had neither and after the first two runs my body had adjusted and it was fine for the rest of the time.ITS A MUST DO THING

Worth a visit. We had been looking forward to visiting the Ski Dome in Dubai for a long time having read many good reports about it and although it is amazing to see something like this in the middle of such a hot country, we were a little disappointed. There were LOTS of people on the slopes who obviously coudn't ski - making it very dangerouse for everyone else. It was all very tired looking and a bit grubby and there were only 2 slopes (not sure what I was expecting!). On the plus side - it was well organised, they lend you everything apart from gloves and there is a lovely little cafe half way down which does great hot chocolate with marshmallows. Like I say - worth a visit but don't expect too much.

An amazing snow experience in a desert country!. Ski Dubai is totally an experience worth the visit. Ski Dubai is located in the Mall of the Emirates, right next to the Kempinski Hotel. This is also a Metro stop. And you have to visit Ski Dubai to know what I mean. A complete section of the mall is converted into this giant ski and snow park area which is many stories high. There are basically three type of entries for the full day: one for the basic snow park, two for partial entry on the ski slope and third full access. Rates vary as per. It is advisable to wear pants and a full hands T shirt, but they will also will be providing protective clothing and boots with complementary socks. Kids are made to wear helmets as well. Also please carry your own gloves and snow cap, or else you will have to buy in their shop, as they don't provide those.Inside the snow park near the entry there will be a photographer from kodak ready to take your pix whose purchase is optional but very expensive. And then its all fun inside. I enjoyed it more so as I come from a hot country and frankly have never played in artificial snow with my young daughter before this. She was thrilled. We spent a good three hours inside the snow park area on the slides and the tyres, etc. You can carry your mobile phones inside but there is no network. Also you can carry your own cameras but there are no pockets on the outfits provided so keeping the camera is problematic. There is a separate viewing area for spectators and snaps can be clicked from there as well. And they do have a locker facility which is chargeable, so keep all your valuables or purchases in the car before entering ski Dubai. Kids below three years not allowed.I totally loved this novel attraction and would definitely recommend it to all just for the kicks.

Fantastic larger than life attraction - a 'must do' experience in Dubai.. Ski Dubai is a fantastic, surreal and larger than life experience.We visited early morning, booking a 'Discovery lesson' at 10am on a weekday. We arrived at 9.15am as suggested, changing into boots, outerwear and skis as provided (bring your own gloves and hat).We were lucky as the lesson was empty and it ended up just being the two of us, therefore receiving a private lesson for the price of a group lesson.The instructor, Nina, was fantastic- patient, encouraging and very helpful- by the end if the hour we could both ski down the smaller slopes at speed, stop etc... A really fun experience, something I doubt one would be able to experience any where else.One thing annoyed us- there are guys who take your photos inside, ski-ing, on the travelator etc this is all harmless fun and doesn't get in the way- however, when it comes to the option of purchasing- they wanted UK£80 to purchase a CD of 40 photos!!!! It makes all the posing for photos a complete waste of time! Take in your iPhone or slim camera instead and snap away / video yourself etc works a treat to get a couple of souvenir snaps.Overall- an absolutely fantastic experience. A definate must do experience- loved it!

A must for anyone. Skiing in the desert is an experience not many can share. It is definitely great fun for the whole family, I was under a great impression of how big the premises are. There are 2 lifts, one intended for intermediate skiiers and another one for advanced users. The slope is not challenging, but there are areas where you can really get yourself going fast so beware. Included in the price (2 hours are included in the preliminary charge) are a set of skis, and a winter outfit, but remember to take your own gloves, cause you can't rent gloves and the one in the shop adjacent to the site are pretty expensive. Even if you can't ski there is a winter park where people who have never experienced snow can play and slide on rafts. All in all it was a wonderful experience and when I visit Dubai again I will certainly go skiing again!

Skiing in the desert on real snow - Fab. Visited Ski Dubai last week and had great fun. All the gear is provided EXCEPT hats and gloves. You can purchase cheap ones there but better to take them if you can.It was pretty busy when we got there and it took three attempts to get boots to fit my partner (mine were fine straight away) but once we were in, it was great. About 400 meter ski slope with various grades with a coffee stop half way down. Two lifts (a drag and a 4-chair) take you slowly to the top. Only concern was that I was twice hit by out of control locals who could barely ski and were going at speeds way above their ability levels. Didn't see anyone pulling these sort of skiers to one side and telling them to slow down. Use the Entertainer voucher to get two for one to make it more economic. A two hour session (more than enough on the one slope) was 180 Dihrams but you pay extra for a locker so budget on 200.

NOTHING LESS THAN AWESOME. A must must visit and dont see it through the Windows. Need to go inside and feel the snow. It is worth Million dollars and get to be there with 200AED only.Very Well Made and This guys have worked out to make it a prefection. Keep Going and best time to go there is in the morning for comparitively the crowd is also minimum so get to enjoy more. You have sledges and everything to do without going to Tundra's

brilliant place to be in. This is one of the wonders in Dubai in the desert city with temp even crossing 50 C. This is in one of the well organised Mall of emairates and this sking facility maintains snow for sking and also it has a snow park to play inside. they maintain the temp around -4 C and its a wonderful feeling. Must see in Dubai.

Expensive. I have been to ski Dubai's snow park with my children a few times. I have noticed that the entrance fee has doubled since the park first opened. It now costs Dhs.120 which is £20 to enter the park and there is no such thing as a family ticket. It costs the average family over £100 to enter. You can stay inside for as long as you like but most of the time people stay not much more than an hour because you start feeling too cold and It gets boring after a while. Good to go once but that's about it.

You feel in a funny freezer. If you are going to Dubai you shouldn't miss this big attraction: Ski Dubai. It's located inside of the Mall of the Emirates at Sheikh Zayed Road. To do skying there you will not need to have your own clothes. You just pay a day fee and get all inclusive! It's quite strange: you go to the mall to buy stuff and can decide last minute to jump into this funny freezer. It smells inside like those smell from when you buy a new freezer. Crazy. Anyway, the slopes are very nice if you are not a professional skier: they are really easy and you get to the bottom in a couple of seconds. It's not crowded, so go anytime.
Really enjoyed it, I took a lesson as I.... Really enjoyed it, I took a lesson as I have never snowboarder before, and it was awesome! Great teacher

Gone downhill. I have been to Ski Dubai on many occasions and have noticed the slowing of the lift for non-skiers in recent months. Whilst this might not sound like a big issue, it makes the ride up the slopes very slow (eight mins) and consequently the cold sets in very quickly. There is a drag lift up the side of the "experts" slope which is much faster but this is not always operational. I was told the drag is used when the slope is busy but I couldn't not find out exactly when the drag does operate, so it is probably a cost saving tactic. Also the expert run is closed for events some evenings. Disappointing for experienced skiers, so check before you set out.

Fun Place for families. I can't comment about the ski slopes since I'm not a skier, but had an absolute blast at the snow park located within Ski Dubai. . We visited the snow park during hot and humid July and -5 degrees was a welcome relief. All protective clothing are provided in your sizes, except for gloves. We knew this in advance so carried our own. You can also use a locker to store your belongings.The snow park is geared mostly towards kids, our three year old son had fun trying out most rides. There are eye catching ice sculptures all around the park, making for nice photos. A cafe (St Moritz, I think was the name) serves some finger food and hot drinks. Activities like rope climbing will keep kids occupied for hours. All in all, a fun way to spend a afternoon in Dubai.

Me and my wife must have caught this.... Me and my wife must have caught this place on a bad day , it was full of rude yobs hitting in to people and throwing snow at people !!! They were horrible to everybody , even the staff turned a blind eye to it , I asked one of the staff if these ppl go there often and I got looked at in such a way it was so so rude !! A real bad experience !!!!! Sorry folks !!!!!

If you ski have a go.. Ski Dubai is well worth a visit. My son and I, who both ski reasonably well, spent a very enjoyable 2 hours there this week. I'm not sure 'd bother if you can't ski and and are only there for the day. Just look through he window fom the Mall. Remember to bring decent gloves and a hat. I don't think I've ever been as cold even in the Alps. Otherwise you can buy them reasonably cheaply at the neighbouring ski shop. The hot chocolate at the mid-slope Avalanche Cafe is highly recommended.One noticeable change since our last visit was the increase in non-skiiers just going up and down on the chairlift for the novelty value. It's certainly an experience seeing people pass you on a ski lift in full Emirati dress however the constant slowing down of the lift to let them on is a bit of a nuisance if you've paid to ski. It crawls along and really cuts your time on the slope down. I would recommend going at 10am when the slope opens. It's much quieter then.

Only do it if you can already ski or be prepared to pay a lot for many lessons. Spent a whole day here with our 4 kids. Two could ski and two could not. We paid for the basic lessons for the younger ones ( 10 and 12 ) but were told they would have to have 2 more classes before they could use the slope and that was it. There is no beginner slope for anyone except those in a lesson, and if you go to the main slope and can't ski, they will not allow you, and not refund your money. We saw this happen to a couple. We decided on no more lessons and paid extra for them to just use the snow park. A very expensive exercise given the cost of the basically useless lesson.Having said all that, those of us that could ski had a great time, and the two younger ones had fun in the park but would have liked to have joined the rest of us.
A wonderful place to visit. We enjoyed our visit to Ski Dubai at Mall of the Emirates very much. Kids enjoyed playing with snow alot.
Nice experience to Everyone in Dubai to see the Ski Dubai. I just went there to see what it was on a 3 day trip to Dubai. We fall in the love with the SKI Dubai and spend all most all 1\2 day there

Funny attraction. Very fun.
You can entry only to visit inside and to take pictures. It's a little bit expensive (100AED), but very interesting.
I think to do !!!!

Something different in Dubai. I feel Ski Dubai rates higher on novelty value (being a ski field in a desert country) than on snowfield value. I pre-booked and took my children for a skiing lesson. We were advised to get there 45 minutes ahead of the lesson to collect all the gear, get fitted for skis etc. We needed every minute of the 45 minutes as the outfitting area was chaotic, to say the least. A major issue was that the staff behind the counter would guess the size of the person in front of the counter, and then would have to go all the way to the back of the store area to collect gear. Customers were then sent off to change. There appeared to be no designated area for people to come back to if the gear didn't fit, so we had people pushing into queues through the exit gates trying to exchange their outfits for different sizes. We also experienced large families lining up, but apparently having no idea what size everyone was; it took one family in front of us 25 minutes to get outfitted. All in all, simply getting the kids outfitted and to the lesson meeting point in time was a very stressful experience.To make matters worse, the children (sensible kids aged 11 and 13) didn't enjoy their lesson because they said the instructor was surly and unhelpful. I would recommend this as a novelty experience if you can already ski, but not as a way of introducing your kids to skiing. It's more fun to watch from the comfort of the St Moritz cafe.

Fun in the snow!. I had a lot of fun here with my friends. None of us ski so we enjoyed all the other activities there like toboggoning. We also took the chairlift to the top. Halfway through there is a little cabin where you could buy hot chocolate and snacks. Too bad we left our wallets in the lockers!Of course, it's very cold there so come prepared. Even though they do provide ski pants, jackets and shoes, it would've been nice if we had worn clothes with long sleeves underneath or maybe even had gloves.
Fun. Fun. Fun. Snow in the desert. If you coming to Dubai, you need to see this. And get in Ski Dubai for a few hours of COLD FUN in the desert. Great installations inside Mall of the Emirates.

For a novice - excellent, but check how busy it is first.. I had 7 days to spend in Dubai whilst working so each evening I tried something new. Ski Dubai is at the end of Mall of the Emirates so there are lots of shops, food stops, etc to see if some of the family don't want to ski. Check out the website first since it is made quite clear that the main slopes are only for people who won't put others at risk or spoil the enjoyment of others. Before I paid, the cashier asked me several questions and warned me that if I wasn't good enough (I had skied once before on a dry ski slope) I may be prevented from skiing and be required to undertake lessons (which may need to be pre-booked. Everything was fair and clear. The staff were excellent and advised upon correct skis and boot fitting. The equipment was in good condition and everything was included in the price (UAE Dhs 210 - £30)(you get Dhs 10 back at the end when returning the electronic key). Being very cautious about not getting ejected or causing a hazard, I started on the upper nursery slope and gained confidence again in snow ploughing. After 4 or 5 attempts, I moved up to the lower section of the main slope (this is when the timer started) and did the same, getting faster and practicing turns and stopping. Finally, I progressed to the top (which splits in two for more experienced and less experienced skiers). The first couple of runs were gradual and again I was able to build up confidence and skill - the ticket was for 2 hours, but my electronic tag gave me three hours for some reason - this was more than enough as I actually skied for about 2. The timer only starts once you use the ski-lift so all the nursery slope practice (which uses a conveyor belt) didn't start the clock running (useful!!!).I went at about 8pm on a Wednesday and ended at 11pm. For the whole of this time, the place was not busy and by the last hour, I sometimes had the whole piste to myself - excellent for practicing and using the whole slope. I didn't use the most advanced section at all - It is clearly for more experienced skiers - one of my work colleagues seriously broke his collar bone by going on the steep slope first on a previous visit!!Considering the infrastructure and quality of everything, this was excellent value for money. I returned on Thursday night, but noted it was much busier and decided not to use the ski facility (remember Friday and Saturday are the main days off work for most Arabic countries). There were lots of helpful staff on hand and I had no complaints - quite the opposite - as a novice skier, this was a perfect introduction and well worth it.The place was a very comfortable -2 degrees and with no wind, I wore just a T-shirt and trousers under the ski equipment provided (they even give you socks) - I didn't need gloves or a hat (but being from the UK I am used to the cold).It was so nice to get out of the heat outside and on the previous 2 nights I had gone to the Ice rink at the Dubai Mall - again well worth a visit!!!

Virtual Tours of Ski Dubai. Hey, I went there and had a blast. I've hard to imagine how unreal is feel to hit the slopes when it's 120 degree outside. Don't forget about the Snow Park Cafe and Snow Park itself. Just take a look at ths virtual tour of the place at http://fayettevillevt.com/community_tours/0001/ski_dubai.htm

If only someone had warned us!!. Ski Dubai is situated at the Emirates Mall - which means you can go shopping if preferred! There's an indoor viewing platform so you can have a look to see what it's all about... We just turned up, and then found out that if you couldn't ski (none of us could), you weren't allowed on the slopes until you'd had a competence lesson (180 AED) which lasted two hours - and had to be pre-booked. The only area we could go in was the kids slopes/playground - and with three teenagers that wasn't going to happen. If we had realised prior to going, that we needed to have a lesson first, we would have pre-booked and then gone back later in the week to enjoy the slopes. Also, check the times - you can't go onto the slopes until after 2pm.

Ski Dubai. As a theme park it does a great job... go there not wanting fresh powder and various runs and enjoy it for what it is... a theme park and you will have a lot of fun. The Discovery Lesson is great for people who have never touched, seen or skied on snow.the best thing is when it's 42 degrees outside it doesn't feel like -4 at all...If you're a good skier... great for practice.... if you're a novice great for practice... for beginners the instructors are great.enjoy for what it is... a snow themed 'theme park'

Good For Skiers but not for those with Young kids. If you're kids can ski, then this is a great place to come. Mine unfortunately can't. I took my son (3) and daughter (5) to the Ski centre at the end of the very large Mall of the Emirates. Unfortunately, we didn't get to the mall until quite late in the evening and managed to get 2 hours of sledging and taboganning in - we paid nearly £25 per person for the privilege though. And that's the problem I have with this place- if your kids can Ski, then you can vary the activities, on the other hand, my two were soon bored (as was I) of sitting in the inflatable rings to slide down a rather short slope..again and again and again. The taboggan run was the other option but this is not particularly suitable for young kids unless you want to suffer cuts and bruises. From a service perspective all areas were staffed with people who were very polite and helpful. The one problem I had was that I couldn't find a helmet ssuitable for a small child and none of the staff were in that area were particularly helpful in finding the right one. This was the only downside in the service - which may have been due to the lateness of our visit.

Novelty or not, It was pretty fun!. When I realized we were going to Dubai the first thing that popped into my head was, "We have to ski in Dubai just to say we did it!". We really didn't know how hard the hill was going to be. Where I live, we have multiple world class ski hills within a 2 hours drive, so we know the experience at Ski Dubai is just going to be strictly novelty. When we showed up, we paid our 180 AED each and that got us suited up with ski pants, ski jacket (it was a button up ski jacket, I can't say I've ever worn a button up ski jacket before), boots and skis (or snowboard for the boarders). The 180 AED gave us 2 hours of ski time and we're able to freeze the time if we decide to grab some food during the experience.I liked the fact that there were a lot of lockers to put our stuff in, and the facilities were very clean. Going up the escalator with ski boots on was an experience, and they had a wide variety of ski poles to choose from which was good.We get into the hill after going through the revolving door and it was a perfect -2C, just like home on a good ski day. Right away we see the kids on the left with their inner tubes flying arond at the bottom of the hill (it's closed off for kids with helmets), and we decided to head to the ski lift. The whole run lasts about 5 minutes if you go all the way to the top, and it's basically a big Green Run experience. The expert section of the hill is a Green run that is slightly narrower than the regular section. The skills section of the hill was closed unfortunately so we couldn't try the rails and the jumps.We ended up skiing for about 90 minutes until we had enough, there was only so much we can handle before it just got redundant. For those who have never skied or snowboard before, this would be a perfect hill to learn on. When we went there were next to nobody there. At all times there were maybe 20 people on the hill at one time so there were a lot of space. For experienced skiers and snowboarders, it's fun and enjoyable, and the fact that you're skiing/snowboarding in a desert is pretty cool itself. But it got old after 90 minutes for us. Either way, it was pretty fun nonetheless.

Ski Dubai is great fun - and you'll know you'll be warm again outside!. Ski Dubai is great fun and we go fairly often. Those who say it’s not as good as the real thing are missing the point: it’s indoors and in the middle of a desert for goodness sake! It’s like comparing lying in your bath to swimming in the ocean.The temperature is around -2C so don’t under-estimate how wrapped up you have to be to be comfortable, I certainly wouldn’t do it without hat and gloves. You have to bring your own but jackets, over-trousers, disposable socks and of course skis boots and poles are included in the fee. I’ve never had a problem with dirty or smelly trousers or jackets as some reviewers have mentioned. I love the fact that when I start to feel the cold I can take comfort from the fact I'll be walking out of there back into hot sunshine.They claim to have the world’s only indoor black run but that’s an exaggeration, however, we are experienced skiers and find it very enjoyable. There is a magic carpet for beginners and that section is separated from the main slopes so beginners are more comfortable.Like a real slope there are sometimes out of control teenage snowboarders flying around and my one criticism is that staff make no efforts to keep them in check.One of the cutest things to see is grown men in dishdashas (the national dress) playing around in the snow park when they are probably experiencing snow for the first time, makes me smile every time.

Excellant. I did go to Dubai last September, very busy place with hectic transport but patient drivers. A must see is the Arabian Gulf to have a swim in the clear water. Another must see is the Mall of Emirates to watch the snow ski while having a coffee. High tea at the Burg is a must. I would like to go back when Dubai Land opens in 2010 which will be bigger than any Disney land in the world. A ride out in the dessert is great. I stayed at Rydges Hotel with good staff & meals but an older Hotel.Betty Johnson

Ski Dubai - It can only happen in Dubai!. This is worth a look at even if you don't wish to ski. Go to the Mall of the Emirates and if you are hungry, go to Apres for food. It is excellent. You can request for a table overlooking Ski Dubai - that's what we did and it was a greta way to spend a couple of hours watching the snowboarders and skiiers.

Kids and Adults Alike with LOVE Ski Dubai!. What fun! Ski Dubai was a definite highlight of our trip. A family of skiers, we were impressed with the runs (given that we were in a mall)! The experience was what was most memorable. Skiing indoors in a dessert while watching shoppers and diners through the large glass windows was a hoot!Our 2 hour ski package was just right, and the hot chocolate at the mid-hill cafe was a perfect ending.A second day, we went for snow play and my children did not want to leave. If you are on a budget, take the snow play pass as it has no time limit, allowing one to really stretch the fun!

Sure beats shopping. Ski Dubai. The legend. If nothing else, it is fascinating. The snow quality is quite good. Since the sun doesn’t shine on it, it doesn’t get icy. The run is a little short for our taste (a few hundred feet vertical drop), but it is amazing to think you are doing this in the desert. We found that in the late afternoon some local boys came and they skied very recklessly, so be careful and consider coming earlier in the day.You purchase your lift ticket for 2 hours and can then add additional hours. For the price, everything is included – lift ticket, ski rental, outer clothes. The only thing not included is your hat and gloves to keep warm. You can purchase them at the local ski shop or just outside Ski Dubai at the H&M store. I would also recommend you take a pair of heavy, knee-high socks. We both had low cut socks and the boots rubbed raw places on our calves.More on our time at Ski Dubai:http://justanothertravelblog.blogspot.com/2009/02/ski-dubai.html
so exciting. my visit on skie dubai had given me un forgettable picture in my mind

Just do it, for the novelty. We went to Ski Dubai and, while skiing this is not the most challenging slopes by any means, the mere fact that you are skiing in the desert was a true novelty. We did get somewhat bored of skiing the same slope, and truly 2 hours is more than enough to get your taste of the facility. Oveall, I would recommend it.

Sooo much fun!!. We spent the day at the Mall of the Emirates today and since my wife had never skied before, we decided to try the Beginners Tutorial at Ski Dubia. It was an amazing experience to be skiing in the UAE... a nice change from the Desert Safari's and beach resorts that you'd expect. Ski Dubai is an engineering marvel and definitely something you should try out!The ski area is quite large and offers a number of slopes of varying difficulty. The temperature inside is quite cold so I DEFINITELY RECOMMEND GETTING GLOVES AND A CAP. If you haven't skied in a while, or never at all, I definetly recommend the Beginners Tutorial, but novice skiers should be able to handle the basic slopes without instruction. More experienced skiers will probably jump straight to the Black Slope that's 400 meters long and starts 25 stories up.It may seem a bit costly, but keep in mind that Jacket, Pants, Boots, Optional helmet, and Ski's are all included in the price. Also you'll get 10 AED back when you return your ski pass cards when you leave.Overall we had loads of fun and may even go back to get a few more hours of skiing in before we leave Dubai!

it's More than just OKAY!. Okay, this place is not the Swiss Alps or the mountains of Colorado. Keep in mind that it is manmade and indoors after all this is the UAE (NO SNOW) I have been skiing for over 20 years and I am an expert and I loved the place. It is a great place for those who want to learn how to ski and for kids. It is also a great place to get out of the heat. I would go again and again every time I am in Dubai. My son will be coming with me to Dubai in few days and I signed him up for the 5 days kids ski camp. It is also true you must bring your own gloves because they are not part of the deal but they give you everything else. You can buy cheap gloves at the shop they have. Overall, I think it is a good place to go in Dubai but again keep in mind it is indoors so doesn’t think big.

it's ok. As an asian family who currently stays in Saudi Arabia, we were so excited when my husband got a business trip to dubai. The plan was he would go for a meeting, and me and my 2 kids ( age 2 & 7 ) will spend the day in Ski Dubai. Sounds great, right. I tried to prepare everything, read people's reviews. From which I learned that we need to bring hats and mittens, and it's best to go around 10am, just after they open, to avoid crowds. But turned out, I missed 1 thing. Kids under 2 can't enter the place. It became a huge problem for me since I have to come with my 7 years old son, since kids under 13 has to go with an adult. They suggested me to send my 2 years old daughter to a daycare called Pick a Boo ( level 2, inside Magic Planet ). I went there, paid the fee, and only after that they told me that kids under 3 has to go with an adult. OMG!! After I negotiated, they arranged a nanny for my daughter with AED50/hour extra. So the first hour, I paid AED85, the next hour AED60. After all that, finally we enter the snow park. One funny thing, it's a must to wear helmets for kids. But, the helmets are so small, that it wont fit if your kid's wearing a hat. It's like a mushroom on my son's head. Meaning it just there, not protecting anything. The snow park is not as big as I thought, but it's enough to introduce my son to snow. And he enjoyed it a lot.

eh, not so great. We were so excited to take our 6 year old son to Ski Dubai after looking at the photos on the website...but once we got there it was a different story. We waited in huge lines (it was February 2008) to get our ski suits and boots; the suits and boots were disgusting! I doubt they are ever cleaned because they were still moist from the last people wearing them. By the way, you have to purchase your own gloves and hats if you want them. My husband and his friend decided once we had already purchased the tickets that they weren't going to go snowboarding; they were not impressed. I took our son through the "snow park" while they waited in the mall. I was so not impressed! There wasn't snow unless you call the hard packed gray stuff under our feet as such! My son rode on the little tube "ride" 2 times and he was done. There's really nothing for kids to do there; he had to be 7 for snowboarding (which is why we went there) and he was too old to take the 1st classes for skiing. They offer sleds for kids but the parents obviously are not watching how there kids act with them because my son was knocked down a few times by kids whipping them around. Inside the "snow park" you can climb up a spiral staircase to get to a bridge so you can watch the skiers come down the hill. These are dangerous!!! The treads are very narrow and they're metal with no traction so my son almost fell half way down them (thankfully I grab a hold of the back of his suit). Since there was nothing to do we only stayed inside the park for half an hour or so. It was so not work the money we spent! We will never go back! I think if you've never seen snow you might enjoy this but after winters in Ohio and Oregon this was not worth it.

Great Fun!. We were one of the first customers to go to Ski Dubai a couple of years ago. We loved it and still love it. The snow park is a little boring for our teens who are older now and probably need some ski/snowboarding lessons. But they still love the toboggans and tubing and just being in the snow. It's a refreshing change from the heat in UAE. This last vacation, we went from the beach in the morning to Ski Dubai in the afternoon. We always forget our mittens and gloves but the ones in the shop beside it aren't more than Dhs 10 for the cheap ones. Love it and will always love it!

The best indoor snowpark. The Ski Dubai entrance has two options: Snow park or slope. In Snow park, you have an unlimited time in the park, but once you get out, you can't enter anymore. In slope, you pay for 2 hours with additional charges for each incremental hour after. Both entrance options come with jackets, helmets for kids under 13 years old, boots, socks and equipments.Snowpark: It's very good and clean, with different games to play (bobsled, tobogganing, etc). it's perfect for non-skiers/boarders and for children. They love running around the park and it's perfectly clean and safe.Slope: They have different levels of slope, but the beginner's level is a bit higher than what you'd find in regular ski slope. The only drawback to this is, you can only do slope if you can ski/snowboard. If you want to do self-discovery, you have to take the lessons, you can't do it yourself. If you fall too often, they have the rights to remove you from the slope. So it is perfect for intermediate and expert skiers/boarders, and perfect for beginners who want to take lessons. Either way, it is by far the best and biggest snow park I've been to. Tip: if you purchase slopes entrance and locker space, save the keycards, cause you get 10 durhams for each keycard back if you return them. Pretty cool huh?

Its gotta be done... even if once!. I would I say agree with much of the reviews in that respect that yes it is something you SHOULD do while out in Dubai and having done it you will probably say been there, done that and move on.Yup as expected its cold, but you do get necessary equipment inside though i remember the hats and gloves you buy were a little on the dear side. Having said that, my wife and I had a good laugh inside, though she did start feeling rather cold after a bit so we called it a day.There are a few activities and a few ice sculptures inside and the ski-ing area looks great though we didn't fancy it!Overall, go for it, experience the cold within a hot country and enjoy!

Only in Dubai. For shear novilty factor, this is something that has to be done whilst on holiday in Dubai.You can choose to going skiing, or just enter the snow park.The skiing is really only designed for novice skiers and it will come as no surprise that the real thing is better... but this is a bit unfair considering Dubai is in the middle of the desert.The snow park is below the ski slope and has toboggins, tubes and plenty of photo opportunities. You can stay in the snow park for as long as you want, but 1 hour is enough.The only thing that you may wish to purchase is a pair of woolen mittens / ski gloves from the shop between purchasing your ticket (electronic swipe card) and collecting the rest of the clothing and equipment.Hot Tip: As mentioned in the Wild Wadi reviews, you can purchase "The Entertainer" book [--] and gain entry to ski dubai using a 2-4-1 voucher.Afterwards, you can enjoy lunch/dinner by the fire at the adjacent St Moritz cafe using another "Entertainer" voucher.After dinner and shopping etc, go to see the music/lights/fire show at the fountain at the valet car parking entrance. This happens every 30 minutes and is best seen at night.I almost forgot... use yet another entertainer voucher to get Hagan Das ice creams for you and your partner whilst watching the light show.BTW: I don't work for "The Entertainer".

Ski Dubai. We went shopping at the Mall of the Emirates & came across Ski Dubai. We booked it & had a great time. One thing to remember is to book early ! We booked at 10.00am & it was not crowded at all but when we came out 2 hours later it was bedlam. The clothing is adequate but stank from the previous user !!!!. They did replace it though. We enjoyed it as did everyone we saw on the slopes or in the snow park.

Novel but I prefer the Rocky Mountains. I was in Dubai the other day on a business trip and had a free weekend. Looking for something to do I stumbled across this picture of skiing and discovered that Dubai has a ski area. My home in Colorado in the US is about 30 minutes from the greatest skiing in the world. Naturally I was skeptical but could not resist the novelty of the idea. So a short taxi cab ride brought me to the Mall of the Emirtes and I was standing before a ski lift gazing up the slope about 15 minutes later. The cost of admission provides everything you need except a hat and gloves (which you do need by the way). There was almost no crowd at all so I was able to ride to the top and ski down about once every 6 minutes. The run was short but the experience was great, I enjoyed every second of my 2 hour pass and managed about 18 runs. It left me longing for the slopes of home but for a few hours diversion in Dubai you can't beat it. Take a friend and sit by the fire afterwards, if you close your eyes it find of feels like Colorado.

Great really good fun!. Everything from the snow park, to the snow school was very well done. i have now moved to Dubai and i have regular snowboarding lessons. all the staff are friendly and we experienced. It was amazing to see how a ski slope with temperatures falling to -2 degrees could be such a success even though it is in the middle of the desert. 10 out of 10 from me!

Do it once for the temperature experience.... Great for locals who may not have experienced snow but apart from that not worth the time and effort for experienced skiers. Good shopping in the Mall though!

Wouldn't do it again. It costs 115 Dirhams to get a ski pass, 10 of which is refundable at the end when you feed the pass back into a machine.The rental equipment is not the best, the boots are cheap and the skis are pretty basic. You also get a jacket and salopets (that go over your trousers/shorts) and a locker to put your stuff in. The locker works off the ski pass so don't loose it! You also need the ski pass to get on the lift inside, it has a chip in it and there is a place in the arm of your jacket where it goes. You do not get gloves or a hat so if you planning on going bring your own (don't need the hat in my opinion). I am sure you can buy them there as the place is in the middle of a massive shopping mall!There is not much carrying of skis as there is an escalator that takes you up to the entrance where you pick up your poles. Tip. Check the size of your poles as people just return them to any old slot and all because the big label states 115 cms does not mean that they will be that length, someone could have dumped 125 cms in there.The actual slope is about 400 meters long and turns a dog leg. There is an easy side and a harder side.I haven’t skied on artificial snow before and didn’t really like it. There is a mist that hangs over the place and the visibility is not the best. If you have skied before you will get bored very soon.The ski lift is sooo slow. It takes ages to get up. There is a half way point where you can get off before it turns the dog leg.For a new place it is already looking a little tired and I suspect they have a few problems.On the plus side it was pretty empty. It is probably a great place to learn how to ski.Would I go again? No. I only did it as it sounded wacky to ski then go down the beach but no desire to go back, unlike Wild Wadi ...

Great Idea but badly organised at the moment. We visited Ski Dubai on Thursday in early february. The place wasnt that busy bearing in mind that it was the weekend but it still took us 45 minutes to get in. I was surprised to find that you arent allowed in the skiing area unless you are an experienced skier - so no nursery slopes. Lessons are bookable though but theres a 3 day wait so it wasnt an option for us.We went into the snow park instead and whilst it was a nice novelty and my kids loved it I couldnt help thinking that it could be much better run. Not enough sledges, several parts closed etc etc.I'm sure things will improve with time and I'll visit again. Just dont expect a well-run attraction just yet...
